comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: This is Robert S. Woodward "Robert Simpson Woodward (July 21, 1849–June 29, 1924) was an American physicist and mathematician, born at Rochester, Michigan." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Simpson_Woodward In 1915, he was named on a new naval board. - the Washington times, September 13, 1915, HOME EDITION, Page 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1915-09-13/ed-... - the Ogden standard, September 20, 1915 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85058396/1915-09-20/ed-... Other members of this board were Thomas Robins and Alfred Craven

comment.author: 35075914@N06
comment._content: Thanks for the info!  We'll update record.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: The Naval Advisory Board was a brainchild of the Secretary of the Navy, who asked Thomas Edison to lead a committee of the best American scientists. Each academy in each of the sciences was then asked to nominate two members to serve. Woodward was nominated through the American Mathematical Society , Craven through the American Society of Civil Engineers, and Robins through the Inventor's Guild. books.google.com/books?id=1poSAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA371&d... Earlier appointees from 1915 to the Board, from the Bain collection: Matthew B. Sellers Elmer Ambrose Sperry A group photo of the Board's first meeting: select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0E12F93C5D1773...
